body:
This is tricky one, but only because type `java.lang.Object` is somewhat overloaded. In many contexts it is taken to mean "use natural types", that is, mapping JSON into combination of `Map`s, `List`s, `String`s and wrappers. So this may be why typing does not work.

I think you are right in that it should work, so above is just speculation of what might be going wrong.

A simple unit test would help diagnosing here, although I should be able to compose one if you don't have one. There are existing tests for default typing just not for this combination of calls.

Actually I do think that I need the unit test here.

This may also be related to long-standing ideas of needing distinction between serialization type (for which existing functionality is designed; use given type instead of real runtime), and base type used for polymorphic handling. The two are tightly bound, but they shouldn't be: in your case, you'd want to use this as base type, but not for serialization of properties.

serialization-type defines the perspective to take when looking at an object. It controls what properties will or will not be included depending on how we look at the object. It is usually determined by the runtime type of the object but we can overwrite it using writerFor method.

What base-type is going to tell us about?
Would it just tell the type of the object as if it was declared as a field?
Sounds like default-typing is actually taking this type into account in order to decide whether to include the type information or not.

So my idea is that writerFor(Class) is not actually a good place to fit it in. We need a way to distinguish between the two concepts.
May be we need another method like writerForDefaultType(). I'm not sure

Base type tells, during serialization, what is the expected type given for `readValue()`, basically. Or, technically, what `@JsonTypeInfo` definition is to be used, so, class for which it is used (usually directly, but possibly via base class). Base type is the starting point for polymorphic type resolution; but actual properties included may only exist in actual subtype that was serialized.

So yes, it would essentially tell declared type of the field, since that is typically the main piece of contextual information available during deserialization.

And yes, you are following with the ideas I have had: separate base type. I have almost implemented it twice already, but both times started doubting whether this was needed, and what would be the canonical use case...

What would be great would, I think, be a unit test that shows the problem with existing usage; case where `writerFor(...)` does not work. So far I have thought that this mostly applies to container types (like `List` or `Map`); if a POJO type could be demonstrated that would be great.
I think #789 might be duplicate here, closing as dup.
Actually I think I should keep this issue open, being specific, and close the other issue since it is more general and has no related issues as of yet.

issue.title: Add method `ObjectWriter.forBaseType(class/JavaType)` for tricky polymorphic cases

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: Duplicate of an existing (usually earlier) issue

repository.name: jackson-databind
repository.description: General data-binding package for Jackson (2.x): works on streaming API (core) implementation(s)

issue.body:
Currently forcing of type information for `ObjectWriter` only allows specifying both implementation type to use (for locating `JsonSerializer`) AND "base type" used by `TypeSerializer`. Since behavior varies between the two, there are cases where one would want to use different type, to specifically force use of a particular base type to produce type id(s) desired.

As far as I can see, this is only needed on writer (serialization) side: during deserialization, there is no distinction between actual runtime type (of an instance) and base type, and a single type works for both.

rename.from: Default typing does not work with writerFor(Object.class)
rename.to: Default typing does not work with `writerFor(Object.class)`

body: @hoomanv Belated thank you for reporting this; will finally be fixed in 2.10.0, to be released with in 2 weeks (and was included in pre-release 3)
